Award.AwardTitle: Estimation, Prediction, and Extremes of Multivariate Random Fields
Award.AbstractNarration:
Data sets with multivariate measurements obtained at spatial locations are nowadays ubiquitous in many scientific areas, ranging from astronomy, environmental, and ecological sciences to image processing. The need to construct and understand multivariate random fields as models for multivariate spatial or spatio-temporal data has increased dramatically in recent years. However, the development of statistical theory and methodology for multivariate random fields is still in an evolutionary stage and poses substantial challenges. This research project is focused on establishing novel results and opening new research directions in parameter estimation, prediction, and extreme value theory of multivariate random fields. It is anticipated that the results of the work will further promote the applicability of multivariate random field models in statistics and other scientific areas. Moreover, involvement in the research will train graduate students and develop their careers in the mathematical sciences.

The research addresses significant questions in statistical inference and extreme value theory of multivariate random fields. Special emphasis is placed on investigating the effects of smoothness/fractal indices and cross-dependence structures of multivariate Gaussian and related random fields on their parameter estimation and prediction under the framework of fixed-domain asymptotics, and on multivariate extreme value theory. Many of the problems under investigation are intrinsically connected with geometric and topological properties of the multivariate random fields. The principal theoretical findings envisaged by this project include simultaneous estimation of multiple parameters and description of their joint performance, prediction under fixed-domain asymptotics, and precise asymptotics for the excursion probabilities, for multivariate Gaussian and related random fields indexed by the Euclidean space or spheres. In previous work, the investigator developed probabilistic and statistical methods for studying multivariate random fields and resolved several outstanding open problems on excursion probabilities, random fractals, Gaussian random fields, Lévy processes, and fractional Lévy random fields. This project aims to yield novel insights into the understanding of multivariate random fields and quantify the influence of their cross dependence structures on the performance of estimators, kriging and co-kriging, and extreme value theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the award period (July 2016-June 2020), the PI, Professor Xiao, has developed original statistical and probabilistic methods for studying estimation, prediction, and extreme value theory of multivariate Gaussian and related random fields indexed by the Euclidean space or spheres. These random field models arise naturally in various scientific areas including geostatistics, applied mathematics, environmental science, oceanography, hydrology, and mathematical physics.

During 2016-2020, Professor Xiao established a series of significant results on the excursion probabilities and estimation of multivariate Gaussian random fields. The following are the main outcomes of his research:

  • Investigate the effects of cross-dependence structures of multivariate Gaussian and related random fields on parameter estimation, prediction, and the exact asymptotic behavior of the excursion probabilities.
  • Establish geometric/topological properties of the excursion sets of multivariate random fields defined on the Euclidean space or certain manifolds such as the sphere. Investigate the effects of fractal or smooth properties of multivariate random fields on estimation, prediction, and multivariate extreme value theory. 

The research of Professor Xiao has led to a deeper understanding of statistical properties and inference of univariate and multivariate random field models and will further promote their applicability in various scientific areas, including environmental science, applied mathematics, hydrology, oceanography, and mathematical physics.

The research discoveries of Professor Xiao led to more than twenty articles published in peer reviewed journals in statistics and probability and were presented at national and international conferences or at seminars in universities in the U.S. and abroad.

Professor Xiao integrated new discoveries in his research into student training and into courses he taught at Michigan State University, as well as short courses that he taught in summer schools at Northwestern University in the U.S., the CIMPA Research School in Argentina, the South China University of Technology in China, and L'Universit? Lille in France.

The past work of Professor Xiao demonstrated a strong commitment to the identification and career development of young talent in statistical and mathematical sciences. During 2016-2020 Professor Xiao supervised two Ph.D. students [Dr.  Jeonghwa Lee (2019), Dr. Cheuk Yin Lee (2020)]. This NSF grant provided one semester 1/2 support for Jeonghwa Lee and one semester 1/2 support for Cheuk Yin Lee to conduct their dissertation research. Professor Xiao has mentored six visiting post-doctoral scholars [Dr.s L. Fang, H. He, Y. Huo, N. Luan, G. Yang, and X. Yang].

Professor Xiao helped to organize a number of activities related to the topics of his NSF-funded research.  These activities include the Invited Session ``Random Fields in Statistics and Applications" at the Joint Statistical Meeting in Chicago (2016); the Invited Session ``Random Fields in Statistics and Applications" at the 10th International Chinese Statistical Association Conference in Shanghai (2016); the Special Session on ``Gaussian Random Fields: Theory and Applications" at the IMS-China International Conference in Statistics and Probability (2017, 2019);  ``Workshop on Stochastic Processes and Stochastic Analysis" at Zhejiang Gongshang University (2018); ``Workshop on Gaussian Processes and Related Topics" at East China Normal University (2019); and ``Seminar on Stochastic Processes" at Michigan State University (2020).  

Professor Xiao has been actively involved in serving the mathematics and statistics communities. He is a Co-Editor in Chief of Statistics and Probability Letters, a Managing Editor of Journal of Fractal Geometry, an editorial board member of Science in China: Mathematics and Illinois Journal of Mathematics.
